text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 15th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns from work, he takes the elevator to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor on rainy days.
Let me break down the information given and see if I can come up with a logical explanation.
First, the man lives on the 15th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
That makes sense because it's faster than walking up and down, especially if he's starting from the top floor.
In the evening, after work, he takes the elevator up to the 10th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining five floors to his apartment.
So, on normal days, he doesn't go all the way up to the 15th floor in the evening—he only goes to the 10th and walks the rest.
Now, the question is why he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor specifically on rainy days.
Hmm. Let me think about the possible reasons.
One thought is about the weather affecting his choice.
Maybe on rainy days, he doesn't want to get wet, so he takes the elevator all the way up instead of walking up the stairs.
That makes some sense because if it's raining, walking up five floors might mean getting wet or dealing with slippery stairs, which could be dangerous.
But wait, the problem mentions that on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor.
So, he's not just avoiding the stairs in the morning; he's also changing his evening routine.
Another angle is that maybe the elevator isn't working properly on rainy days.
But that seems less likely because the problem doesn't mention any issues with the elevator.
If the elevator were broken, he wouldn't be able to use it in the morning to go to work, which he does every day.
Wait, perhaps it's about the time he takes.
Maybe the elevator is faster than walking up the stairs, but on rainy days, he doesn't want to get his clothes wet or his shoes messed up by walking up the stairs.
So, to avoid getting wet, he takes the elevator all the way up.
That would make sense because walking up five floors in the rain could be inconvenient or uncomfortable.
But let me think deeper.
Is there another reason? Maybe the building has a policy about taking the elevator on rainy days, but that's speculative.
The problem doesn't mention any building policies, so I should focus on the man's actions and the given information.
So, putting it together: on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 15th floor in the evening because walking up the stairs would involve getting wet, which he wants to avoid.
Therefore, the reason is to stay dry by using the elevator instead of walking up the stairs.
Wait, but he still takes the elevator down in the morning regardless of the weather.
So, maybe the issue is only in the evening.
That makes sense because in the morning, he's going down, so it's just about getting to work, but in the evening, he's returning home and might not want to get wet while walking up.
So, the key difference is that in the evening, he has to walk after taking the elevator part of the way, but on rainy days, he avoids the stairs by taking the elevator all the way.
That way, he stays dry.
I think that's the main reason.
So, to sum it up, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor to avoid getting wet when walking up the stairs.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way to the 15th floor on rainy days to avoid getting wet while walking up the stairs, ensuring he stays dry.
